Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of an Implantable Arterial Access System for Chemotherapy and Peripheral Vascular Disease

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included histologically proven colorectal adenocarcinoma with inoperable hepatic metastases and critical limb ischemia with no option but amputation.

Intervention.evidence: This study evaluated an implantable arterial access system for targeted chemotherapy delivery and isolated arterial-to-arterial extracorporeal perfusion in end-stage peripheral vascular disease.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome for chemotherapy was partial response or stable disease over 11.2 months. For peripheral vascular disease, the primary outcome was avoidance of major amputation over 22 months.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This single-arm pilot study included 10 patients with secondary colorectal cancer and 20 patients with critical limb ischemia.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the chemotherapy group, six out of ten patients achieved partial response or stable disease.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the chemotherapy group, six out of ten patients achieved partial response or stable disease. In the peripheral vascular disease group, 40% avoided amputation, and 20% had a delay of 4 months.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included a 4% infection rate and one minor thromboembolic event.
